course_title: Topics in Afr American Studies: African Amer. & Informal Econ.
seats: Seats: Maximum Enrollment: 25 / Seats Avail: 16Waitlist Total: 0
class_notes:
(Complete Topic: African Americans and the Informal Economy)
(This course examines the causes and effects of African Americans' involvement in the informal economy. Students will consider both historical and contemporary ways Blacks have experienced employment discrimination. Theories related to labor supply, wage determination, rational choice, and harm reduction are reviewed. No formal economic training is required. Students will use analytical skills to assess underground economy ecosystems across American cities. Specific attention will be paid to personal impact, policy responses, and portrayal of the illicit economy in the media. Some of the topics covered include the drug war, sex work, gun trafficking, untaxed labor, marijuana legalization,  and organized crime.)
course_description: This course explores one of a wide range of topics pertaining to the African American experience in the fields of human and civil rights, social and literary texts, and the social sciences.
sections: Class Nbr: 2434, Section #: 3, Type: LEC, Campus: ATL, Meets: M 2:40-3:55p, Instructor: J. Stewart, Status: Open
